results.title: Russian-Ukrainian talks end in disappointment
results.content:
Russia's Vladimir Putin and Ukraine's Petro Poroshenko failed to reach a breakthrough to end the crisis in Ukraine, as a tense meeting brokered by European Union leaders in Milan ended in disappointment.

Mr Putin and Mr Poroshenko discussed a number of thorny issues, from allowing drones to monitor the Ukrainian border, to the structure of local elections in the pro-Russian separatist region, reports James Politi in Milan.

They pledged to enforce a truce agreed last month that has since been frequently breached.

Italian premier Matteo Renzi sought to frame the encounter as a chance to reopen the dialogue, but Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov accused some in the room of taking an "absolutely biased, non-flexible, non-diplomatic" approach to Ukraine, offering little hope that an agreement was in the cards.

Some participants seemed to be totally unwilling to understand the actual state of affairs in the southeast of Ukraine and to demonstrate an objective approach.

Mr Cameron said Mr Putin had clearly indicated he did not want a "frozen conflict" or a "divided Ukraine" but the UK premier said the onus was now on Moscow to remove Russian troops and weapons from its neighbouring country.

If those things don't happen then clearly the European Union, Britain included, must keep in place the sanctions and the pressure so that we don't have this sort of conflict in our continent.

French president Francois Hollande also said that talks had hit an impasse:

Things have moved forward but they have not been sorted.

Roman Olearchyk reports that Andrey Purgin, vice prime minister of the Donetsk People's Republic, told news agency Interfax that his self-declared government would not surrender control over the region's border with Russia, and signaled it was also not keen to allow the border region to be monitored by the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe.

Mr Putin arrived in Milan on Thursday night later than expected after attending a military parade in Serbia, forcing a delay in a planned bilateral meeting with Ms Merkel.

He then proceeded to pay a visit to Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian media mogul and former prime minister – and his close personal friend - who was convicted of tax fraud and is serving a one-year community service sentence.

Mr Berlusconi and Mr Putin met at the former Italian premier's apartment in the centre of Milan, rather than his villa on the outskirts of the city after the former Italian prime minister received a green light from judicial authorities, according to Italian media reports.
results.abstract: Russia's Vladimir Putin and Ukraine's Petro Poroshenko failed to reach a breakthrough to end the crisis in Ukraine, as a tense meeting brokered by European Union leaders in Milan ended in disappointment.

results.title: Putin, Poroshenko agree to enforce ceasefire
results.content:
Vladimir Putin and Petro Poroshenko agreed to enforce a ceasefire deal to end the violence in eastern Ukraine, under heavy pressure from EU leaders at a summit in Milan, though a clear breakthrough to end the conflict remained elusive.

Matteo Renzi, the Italian prime minister hosting the meeting between the Russian and Ukrainian presidents, described it as "really positive" – a chance to rebuild ties between the countries after months of hostilities, the FT's James Politi writes.

"Obviously there are a lot of differences but I would underline the real desire to find a solution and for this reason I think we can be positive after this meeting," said Mr Renzi, who added he was hopeful it would lead to "steps ahead" in the coming hours and days.

They also agreed on joint surveillance of the Ukrainian border with drones.

Further meetings were expected to unfold on the margins of the Milan summit in a flurry of diplomatic activity.

The goal of the meeting between Mr Putin and Mr Poroshenko – which also included Angela Merkel, German chancellor, François Hollande, French president, David Cameron, UK prime minister – was to try to find a way to effectively enforce a ceasefire deal that was reached in Minsk last month but has frequently been violated.
results.abstract: Vladimir Putin and Petro Poroshenko agreed to enforce a ceasefire deal to end the violence in eastern Ukraine, under heavy pressure from EU leaders at a summit in Milan, though a clear breakthrough to end the conflict remained elusive.

results.title: Cameron promises lower taxes if elected
results.content:
David Cameron has promised sweeping tax cuts for low and middle earners if he wins the next UK election, as he seeks to position the Conservatives as the party best placed to improve voters' living standards.

Speaking at the annual Tory party conference in Birmingham, the prime minister said the Conservatives would raise the level at which people begin paying income tax from £10,500 to £12,500 a year. This would mean anyone earning under a full-time living wage would not pay any income tax.

Political Correspondent Kiran Stacey reports that in an effort to placate the criticism from some of his MPs that too many middle-income workers have been dragged into the 40p income tax band, Mr Cameron announced the threshold would rise from £42,000 to £50,000 if he wins next year.

The prime minister told delegates: "If you put in, you should get out, and not hand so much of it back to the taxman... We want to cut more of your taxes. But we can only do that if we keep on cutting the deficit... Tax cuts need to be paid for."

Mr Cameron also promised a future Conservative government would continue with its pledge to have the lowest corporate taxes in the G20 group of nations, including the US, Japan and Germany.

The Tory leader repeated his finance minister's pledge that multinational companies must pay the taxes they owe - a reference to tech companies such as Google and Apple, which have been accused by some of exploiting low-tax havens such as Ireland and the Netherlands.
results.abstract: David Cameron has promised sweeping tax cuts for low and middle earners if he wins the next UK election, as he seeks to position the Conservatives as the party best placed to improve voters' living standards.

results.title: UK conducts first air strikes against Isis
results.content:
The UK has conducted its first airstrikes against Islamist militants, a week after David Cameron vowed to tackle the "mortal threat" they posed.

Two RAF Tornados came to the assistance of Kurdish troops engaging fighters from Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant, known as Isis, in the northwest of Iraq, the Ministry of Defence said on Tuesday.

An Isis armed pick-up truck was also attacked in the same area, according to the MoD, which added that initial assessments suggested the strikes were successful.

The UK government won backing from Parliament on Friday for the strikes against militants who have taken control of parts of northern Iraq and parts of Syria.
results.abstract: The UK has conducted its first airstrikes against Islamist militants, a week after David Cameron vowed to tackle the "mortal threat" they posed.

results.title: S&P removes negative outlook on India's rating
results.content:
Standard & Poor's has lifted its negative outlook on India's creditworthiness, citing the "more conducive" reform environment after the landslide election of Narendra Modi's BJP party earlier this year, which the rating agency hopes will boost the sleeping giant's growth potential.

S&P affirmed India's BBB- rating, its lowest investment grade, and moved its outlook from negative to stable – for now, removing the threat of a downgrade to "junk" status.

The move buoyed the Indian stock market, helping the Sensex index reverse an earlier decline to climb 0.4 per cent on the day.

In the statement, the rating agency said:

India's improved political setting heralds a more conducive environment for reforms, providing a boost to growth prospects and the potential for improved fiscal management.

... The stable outlook reflects our expectation that the newly elected government will be able to implement reforms that spur growth, which in turn improves fiscal performance.

Investors have also grown increasingly optimistic that India's economy can shed its lethargy and rediscover the vim that the last Congress party government briefly managed to inspire in its first term.

In addition to the reform-minded Mr Modi, the new central bank governor Raghuram Rajan has eased the concerns of many fund managers that the country would struggle as the Federal Reserve prepares to tighten monetary policy.

The Sensex has climbed 24.7 per cent this year, the fourth-best performance in the world, while the Indian rupee has been one of the few emerging market currencies to hold onto its gains versus the dollar this year.

BlackRock's Investment Institute published a paper on India today authored by senior fund manager Ewen Cameron Watt, which said:

India has gone from a castaway market to investor darling – in the space of a year.

Modi and Rajan have set in motion an apparent virtuous cycle: increasing business confidence, accelerating economic growth, deficit reduction, receding inflation, a stable currency and inbound investment. Modi is acting as a hands-on CEO. He has revived stalled investment projects, further curbed government spending and initiated many small changes that make it easier to do business.
results.abstract: Standard & Poor's has lifted its negative outlook on India's creditworthiness, citing the "more conducive" reform environment after the landslide election of Narendra Modi's BJP party earlier this year, which the rating agency hopes will boost the sleeping giant's growth potential.

results.title: Kiwi consumer confidence rises
results.content:
Kiwis are feeling good about their economy, a day before they head to the polls.

The monthly consumer confidence index from ANZ reported for September was 127.7, up 1.8 per cent from the 125.5 recorded in July - the lowest reading this year.

New Zealand holds its general election on Saturday. In contrast to the fevered predictions about how the results of a certain other vote will affect the economy, the message from Kiwis seems to be that no news really is good news. The ANZ report noties that "consumers appear to be shrugging their shoulders and sayings things look okay."

Economist Cameron Bagrie notes:

Looking for the clearest trend we note it's the lack of one; consumer sentiment has oscillated between 136 and 126 over the past year. There is not across the board euphoria, but it is certainly a story of elevation and liveliness. That's a positive sign for spending trends.

In a cheering detail the report noted that the 18 to 24 year age group reported an 11 point overall increase in sentiment taking their reading to a seven-year high of 147.
results.abstract: Kiwis are feeling good about their economy, a day before they head to the polls.

results.title: Poll gives Scottish 'No' vote the edge; pound jumps
results.content:
Sterling jumped in late afternoon trading in New York after a second opinion poll suggested that the Scottish public will vote against independence next week, allaying fears of a potentially messy break-up of the Union.

The latest YouGov poll published late on Thursday put the 'No' vote at 52 per cent and the 'Yes' vote at 48 per cent.

It sent the pound as high as $1.627.

An earlier poll from YouGov published on Sunday was the first to give the 'Yes' campaign a lead, triggering a sharp slide in the pound and forcing David Cameron and Ed Miliband to scramble to Scotland to make the case for the three-century old Union.

The prospect of a 'Yes' vote has also galvanised British businesses to wade into the debate this week, with companies from BP to Royal Bank of Scotland throwing their weight behind the 'No' campaign.

Peter Kellner, president of YouGov, said that the poll is the first that has shown gains for the 'No' vote since early August.

Scottish voters go to the polls on September 18.

Here is the FT's full coverage of the Scottish independence vote.
results.abstract: Sterling jumped in late afternoon trading in New York after a second opinion poll suggested that the Scottish public will vote against independence next week, allaying fears of a potentially messy break-up of the Union.

results.title: EU unveils new Russian sanctions regime
results.content:
Moscow's sabre-rattling about retaliatory measures doesn't seem to have deterred the Europeans.

Peter Spiegel reports that EU diplomats on Thursday ended a week-long deadlock over a new round of sanctions against the Kremlin, agreeing to trigger measures to block Russia's largest state-owned oil companies from raising money on European capital money on Friday.

The sanctions were due to go into effect at the start of the week, but several EU countries baulked, arguing they needed more time to assess whether a Kiev-brokered ceasefire would take hold.

Diplomats said the decision by EU ambassadors to press ahead came only after Herman Van Rompuy, the European Council president, held a conference call with the four European G7 leaders – Germany's Angela Merkel, France's François Hollande, Britain's David Cameron and Italy's Matteo Renzi – Thursday morning to finalise the measures.

Under the agreement, EU diplomats will review sanctions against Russia by the end of the month and they tasked the European Commission to offer options for amending, suspending or repealing them. Any suspension of the current measures would need the unanimous backing of all 28 EU members.

"We have always stressed the reversibility and scalability of our restrictive measures," Mr Van Rompuy said in a statement.

The new sanctions will also bar European energy services companies from working on any advanced oil exploration projects in Russia, including deep-sea drilling, Arctic exploration and shale oil projects.
results.abstract: Moscow's sabre-rattling about retaliatory measures doesn't seem to have deterred the Europeans.

results.title: Brit gets EU financial services prize job
results.content:
Britain secured its most prized job in Europe on Wednesday as Jean-Claude Juncker stunned Brussels by tapping Lord Hill, a Tory peer plucked from obscurity, to oversee the bloc's financial services sector.

Alex Barker reports from Brussels that the unexpected move by the incoming European Commission president represents a big gamble and a dramatic olive branch to David Cameron, the British prime minister who aggressively opposed him taking the helm of the EU executive.

Financial services regulation has been the source of discord between London and Brussels in recent years, as the EU has expanded its authority and pushed through contentious measures such as the banker bonus cap.

Mr Juncker's willingness to offer this plum portfolio to Mr Cameron is an indication of how seriously his Commission will take the need to solve "the British question" ahead of a possible in-out referendum.

The nomination will be seen as a victory for Mr Cameron given the rock-bottom expectations in Westminster.

Lord Hill is a former Conservative staffer who worked with Mr Cameron through the 1990s and served in his government as an education minister and as a low-profile leader of the UK upper house.

Prior to his appointment as a minister, the peer spent almost two decades working as a lobbyist, where some of his firm's clients included financial services companies. He has no in-depth knowledge of the financial sector.

More soon on ft.com
results.abstract: Britain secured its most prized job in Europe on Wednesday as Jean-Claude Juncker stunned Brussels by tapping Lord Hill, a Tory peer plucked from obscurity, to oversee the bloc's financial services sector.

results.title: Duchess of Cambridge pregnant with second child
results.content:
Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, is pregnant again, according to a statement from the UK royal family.

The royal family appears to have decided to announce the news because the duchess is suffering from acute morning sickness that needs medical treatment – as happened with the couple's first child, Prince George. This meant she could not accompany Prince William to an Oxford engagement today.

In a statement the Royal family said:

The Queen and members of both families are delighted with the news.

Prime Minister David Cameron was quick to welcome the news, saying on Twitter:

Many congratulations to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. I'm delighted by the happy news that they're expecting another baby.
results.abstract: Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, is pregnant again, according to a statement from the UK royal family.
